difficult airway management.description: Managing a difficult airway involves assessing risk factors like Mallampati score and neck mobility. Video laryngoscopy is recommended for Grade III/IV views. Backup options include supraglottic devices.

rapid sequence induction.description: RSI secures the airway rapidly in aspiration-risk patients. Use preoxygenation and cricoid pressure. Avoid in known difficult airways unless prepared for rescue.

local anesthetic systemic toxicity.description: LAST occurs with high local anesthetic levels, causing CNS and CV symptoms. Treat with 20% lipid emulsion. Prevention includes test doses and ultrasound guidance.

spinal anesthesia.description: Spinal anesthesia uses local anesthetics in the subarachnoid space. Monitor for hypotension and respiratory depression. Ideal for lower limb surgeries.

pediatric airway management.description: Pediatric airways require smaller ETTs (size = [age/4] + 4). Avoid cuffed tubes in infants. Use uncuffed tubes in children under 8 years.

malignant hyperthermia.description: MH is a hypermetabolic crisis triggered by anesthetics. Administer dantrolene and cool the patient. Stop triggering agents immediately.

obesity and airway challenges.description: Obese patients need ramped positioning for intubation. Anticipate difficult BMV due to soft tissue. Use higher initial oxygen flow rates.

cricothyrotomy procedure.description: Cricothyrotomy is a last-resort airway in CICO. Use scalpel-bougie technique within 60 seconds. Confirm placement with capnography.

propofol administration.description: Propofol induces anesthesia with rapid onset. Dose at 1â€“2 mg/kg IV, watch for hypotension. Contraindicated in egg/soy allergies.

sevoflurane use.description: Sevoflurane is a volatile anesthetic for pediatric induction. Monitor for respiratory depression. Risk of malignant hyperthermia exists.

asa difficult airway algorithm.description: The ASA algorithm guides difficult airway management. Limit attempts to 3, use rescue devices, and escalate to surgical airway if needed.

regional anesthesia safety.description: Ensure safety in regional blocks by avoiding intravascular injection. Use nerve stimulators or ultrasound. Monitor for LAST symptoms.

airway management.description: Comprehensive airway management includes assessment, preparation, and execution of airway techniques. Follow AANA guidelines for patient safety.

pharmacology.description: Understanding anesthetic pharmacology is essential for safe practice. Includes pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and drug interactions.

patient safety.description: Patient safety is the foundation of anesthesia practice. Includes monitoring, documentation, and adherence to professional standards.
